body: But then we need an Actions workflow for it as well. Jus removing the threshold is a bit risky
Absolutely. This issue tracks all the work necessary to support python 3.10. I agree regularly testing the code in python version 3.10 is a requirement for that.

issue.title: [MNT] Extend python support to 3.10

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs

- Fixes #2079


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body: I bumped the python version in `pyproject.toml` and updated the GH actions but  the current version of `pystan` does not compile under python 3.10.2 :(

Prophet still depends on [pystan~=2.19.1.1](https://github.com/facebook/prophet/blob/main/python/requirements.txt) so this is blocked until:

- prophet bumps the pystan version that *might* compile against the python 3.10
- we figure out a way of compiling pystan against python 3.10
- we find a way of running a test suite without prophet

There might be some alternative solutions as well.

OK, I think I should've been a bit clearer. Running tests is not a concern at this point since the previous step which installs `sktime` with `all_extras` fails when compiling `pystan` on python 3.10. Without being able to install the package we won't be able to test.
Can we use a python_version < 3.10 environment marker on pystan/prophet in the toml file so that they‚Äôre not installed when installing all_extras?

> Can we use a python_version < 3.10 environment marker on pystan/prophet in the toml file so that they‚Äôre not installed when installing all_extras?

I haven't seen that feature. Essentially it would mean different sets of dependencies for different python, not only the versions of dependencies but also the actual dependency items. Even if we were to somehow make it happen it might prove problematic to actually install the package.

I would probably be closer to dropping `prophet` or isolating it into a dependency group but then we would have to be able to run the test suite selectively without `prophet`.

Here is an example of using environment markers. You put ‚Äú, python_version < 3.10‚Äù after the dependency: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0631/#example

Yea I agree there would be some complexity with selectively skipping tests for prophet but I think it‚Äôs worth it for users since prophet is an optional dependency and it shouldn‚Äôt ‚Äúhold up‚Äù sktime in this situation.
Thanks for the example @freddyaboulton, very helpful. I added the skip for prophet, pystan and esig. Obviously at this stage a lot the tests will break because of import errors.

> I would probably be closer to dropping prophet or isolating it into a dependency group but then we would have to be able to run the test suite selectively without prophet.

We can do that easily if someone would finally be willing to review my test framework improvements üòÅ 
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2023
(which leads to a state where we can selectively control set of estimators being tested, and we could make it dependent on python version if we wanted)

> Sorry, it was a badly phrased question. What I really wanted to ask was whether sktime will support 3.10? Most of the dependencies in pycaret now support this (with the latest release of sklearn) except sktime, so just curious :)

@ngupta23, moving the question from #2631 to here. Perhaps @lmmentel or @freddyaboulton can give you the newest on this?

From discussion in #2651:

Why would non-3.10 compatible soft dependencies prevent us from an upgrade?

We can simply raise warnings and errors with a descriptive message regarding python compatibility, in those problematic soft dependencies? Might take a little bit of tinkering with the soft dependency utility, but surely soft dependencies should not prevent us from supporting python 3.10? That¬¥s also not sustainable in the limit of infinite soft dependencies. I think we should generally decouple python support of sktime from that of soft dependencies.

On the technical side: imports happen only inside class methods, so in construction and class import we can raise the warning, without compromising functionality.

We should also be able to easily exclude classes from testing based on version support, although that also requires some functionality around this.

> we find a way of running a test suite without prophet

I would go with this:
we introduce a `python_max_version` tag for estimators.
I add a line of logic to the test suite (which already supports tag based selection) to exclude estimators that have a lower max version that current in the environment.

How about this?

> > we find a way of running a test suite without prophet
> 
> I would go with this: we introduce a `python_max_version` tag for estimators. I add a line of logic to the test suite (which already supports tag based selection) to exclude estimators that have a lower max version that current in the environment.
> 
> How about this?

I am strongly against that since it's not the role of the estimator to depend on the python version.

> I am strongly against that since it's not the role of the estimator to depend on the python version.

I¬¥m surprised about this statement of yours!

I see `sktime` like a library of libraries. I.e., estimators, many of which interface to other libraries. Those libraries have python version bounds. So it seems natural to attach that property to an estimator.

Note, in my conceptual model I do not consider an estimator to be an algorithm in its abstract, ideal form. I consider it an algorithm in a specific implementation. E.g., ARIMA from statsmodels is a different estimator from ARIMA from statsforecast. Similar to how you have different implementations of linear regression, while the "ideal" form is the same.

As python version compatibility is a property of the implementation, and my conceptual model refers to to an implementation, I think that it is very natural.

Another, more practical argument for my viewpoint: in the "ideal limit", the number of algorithms following the sktime interface (though, not necessarily in sktime itself), or more generally, a scikit-learn like interface, approaches infinity.

In this limit, the individual libraries interfaces will be arbitrarily behind the current python version, e.g., slow to update. That will mean that as sktime grows, it would become more and more difficult to upgrade to newest python, which seems absurd.
